content:
The "Patient Protection Act of 2000" is also known as the Public Availability of Physician Information in National Practitioner Data Bank. It amends the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 to include public availability of physician information. The Secretary must promulgate regulations by January 31, 2001, allowing the public to access physician information while protecting patient identity and personal details. The regulations require the submission of reports on medical malpractice payments, with information to be made available to the public through the Internet. Physician statements must be included in the disclosure, and updates on the information should be provided monthly. The regulations mandate the disclosure of medical malpractice payments, with reports on physicians to be compared to others in the same specialty and state. Payment amounts must be categorized to show their significance. The regulations require disclosure of medical malpractice payments, categorizing them to show significance. Payments may not reflect negatively on a physician's competence. The regulations require disclosure of medical malpractice payments, emphasizing that payments should not imply physician incompetence. Additionally, it states that some physicians who specialize in high-risk cases may have higher malpractice claims due to the nature of their work. Specialty-specific malpractice histories vary, with certain specialties more prone to litigation than others. The disclosure of medical malpractice histories compares physicians within the same specialty or state to provide meaningful information about individual physicians. Malpractice histories can vary by state due to differences in laws, and comparisons are made to relevant peer groups for context. Regulations require disclosures of physician reports to include a statement noting that not all crime-related information may be provided due to varying state laws and self-reporting. Amendments to the Health Care Quality Improvement Act include clarifications on the disclosure of information and the removal of certain fees. Title II of the Health Care Quality Improvement Act mandates reporting requirements for the National Practitioner Data Bank, specifically requiring reports on medical malpractice payments. Section 421(b) of the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 is amended to require reports on medical malpractice payments. This includes details about the physician's medical field, specialty, licensing date, years of practice, license number, and state of licensure. SEC. 202. REPORTING OF SANCTIONS BY BOARDS OF MEDICAL EXAMINERS. Section 422(a) of the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 is amended to include provisions for denying, revoking, or suspending licenses of physicians. This includes reporting the medical field and specialty of the physician. The Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 now requires Boards of Medical Examiners to report information on physicians' criminal acts, including their specialty, years of practice, license number, and state of licensure. The Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 mandates Boards of Medical Examiners to report physicians' felony and misdemeanor convictions, as well as criminal charges where physicians pled nolo contendere. Each Board of Medical Examiners must report requested information to the Secretary for disclosures in accordance with the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986. Amendments are made to section 424 to align with the Act. SEC. 203. REPORTING OF CERTAIN PROFESSIONAL REVIEW ACTIONS TAKEN BY HEALTH CARE ENTITIES. Section 423(a)(3) of the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 is amended to include additional information required for physicians, such as their medical field and specialty, licensing date, years of practice, and professional license number. The Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 requires physicians to provide their professional license number and state of licensure. Federal health facilities and physicians are subject to the same review actions as other healthcare entities under this Act. The Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 requires physicians to report to the relevant Board of Medical Examiners in the state where the Federal health facility is located. Section 432 of the Act is amended to remove subsection (b) and redesignate subsection (c) as subsection (b). SEC. 424A requires physicians to self-report felony convictions under the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986. Physicians must report any felony convictions they have in accordance with specific guidelines outlined by the Secretary. Failure to report such information may result in a civil money penalty of up to $10,000 for each violation. SEC. 205. NOTICE TO PRACTITIONERS; CORRECTION OF INFORMATION. Section 426 of the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 is amended to include a new subsection (b) regarding statements from practitioners about reported information. Practitioners can submit a statement to the Secretary regarding reported information, which will be included in the report subject to certain conditions. The statement can be made at any time and may be revised. Practitioners can submit a statement to the Secretary regarding reported information, limited to 4,000 characters. The Secretary will notify the practitioner about this option and the character limit. TITLE III--DUTY TO OBTAIN INFORMATION

SEC. 301. DUTY OF HOSPITALS TO OBTAIN INFORMATION.

Section 425 of the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 is amended to include Federal hospitals under the same requirements as other hospitals.

SEC. 302. DUTY OF BOARDS OF MEDICAL EXAMINERS TO OBTAIN INFORMATION.

Part B of the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 is amended to include a new section on the duty of boards of medical examiners to obtain information. Effective six months after the Patient Protection Act of 2000, each Board of Medical Examiners must request information about a physician at the time of initial license application and for license renewals. Failure to request this information may result in presumed knowledge of any issues. Each Board of Medical Examiners must request information about a physician at the time of initial license application and for license renewals. The Board can rely on information provided unless it knows it is false. TITLE IV--GENERAL PROVISIONS

SEC. 401. REQUEST OF BOARD OF MEDICAL EXAMINERS REGARDING PHYSICIAN INFORMATION IN NATIONAL PRACTITIONER DATA BANK.

Section 427(a) of the Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 1986 is amended to allow the Board of Medical Examiners of a State to request a summary of information on licensed physicians, including name, address, and report details.

SEC. 402. REGULATIONS; EFFECTIVE DATE. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must issue a final rule by January 31, 2001, to implement the amendments in this Act. The amendments will become effective 30 days after the final rule is issued.
